text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm web snell escargot that's right I
probably shouldn't have posted this on
April 1st since people are gonna think
this meatless version of escargot is
some kind of April Fool's gag which it
kind of is but it was also a very fun
culinary experiment and as everybody
knows one of the toughest things about
becoming a vegetarian is no longer being
able to enjoy snails so every once in a
while I do like to throw our vegetarian
viewers a bone pardon the expression and
so this video is officially dedicated to
them ok so let's go ahead and get
started and what makes this now
L'Escargot
is the fact we're going to use mushrooms
and unlike literally every other food
you eat which is nourished and
controlled by the Sun mushrooms are
ruled by the moon which is why I was
thinking of branding these as moon
snails but the more I thought about it
the more I realize that sounds kind of
stupid so I'm not going to do that but
regardless we are going to stuff our
shells with mushrooms so what I did is I
took a pound of brown mushrooms which I
washed very well and then I took a
paring knife and trimmed off the stem
just above the cap at which point I cut
them in half because I figured once that
was cooked that would be the approximate
size of canned escargot but then I
decided to give it one extra little cut
right through the cap like this about
halfway through and my hope was that
little cut would helps soak in more that
garlic parsley butter and also snails do
have lots of little nooks and crannies
so anyway I went ahead and prepped my
mushrooms as shown and then I knew I was
going to have to cook these somehow
before stuffing them in the shell so I
decided to take a saucepan with a couple
cups of water to which I headed a spoon
of miso and some seaweed because I was
trying somehow to increase the
savoriness of the mushroom and possibly
even give it some hints of flavor that
you might find in us now so I figured
the miso would give me some saltiness
and savoriness and then a little bit of
that nori seaweed might possibly give me
that essence of garden and I believe I
did mention this was an experiment so I
was totally shooting from the hip here
but anyway that's what I was trying to
do and to that end I also added a nice
big splash of soy sauce and I brought
that mixture up to a simmer on high heat
and then once I saw it bubbling I went
ahead and added my mushrooms and then I
reduced the heat to medium-low and
simply simmered them for about 10
minutes stirring occasionally and like I
said I was hoping they would absorb some
of that background flavor from the broth
which as it turns out they really didn't
so if I ever tried these again which I
won't I think instead of liquid I'll
just brown these really really well
which I'm guessing is gonna give them a
lot more meteor flavor which I kinda
already knew in the back of my mind but
hey you really don't know for sure until
you try something I mean ask anyone that
doesn't try things they'll tell you but
anyway like I said we simmer those for
about 10 minutes at which point they
look like this so they definitely shrunk
up as cook mushrooms will do and once
those mushrooms are cooked I just turned
off the heat and decide to just let them
sit that liquid while we prepped our
snail last Skaar go butter which is
going to be remarkably similar to a
classic escargot butter so we'll start
with 1/2 a cup of margarine April Fool's
just kidding margarine is not real food
so don't eat it we're actually going to
start with some real high-quality
unsalted butter to which we're going to
add a ton of garlic that was like four
or five very very finely minced cloves
we will also do a little bit of minced
shallot they have that in all the
grocery stores now and then of course a
handful of freshly chopped Italian
parsley that is mandatory and then we're
also going to want to season this up
with a very generous pinch of salt some
freshly ground black pepper and then so
they know it's one of ours
a little shake of cayenne and then last
but not least to French this up a little
bit I'm going to give it a little splash
of Perrineau oh yeah the D is silent in
fact the O is almost silent if you
haven't had a pair know has sort of a
licorice flavor
okay think the herb tarragon that's sort
of the flavor profile so I'm gonna go
ahead and add a little bit of that and
then we'll take a fork and we'll mash
that all together so a fairly intensely
flavored highly seasoned mixture
remember this stuff was originally
invented to make people forget they were
eating garden slugs although I'm
guessing slugs and snails are different
and now I'm going to get a bunch of
emails from people with too much time on
their hands you know people like me but
anyway like I said let's go ahead and
mix that up and once that's that we can
move on to final production so what I
did is I drained my mushrooms and of
course made the fatal flaw of not
tasting them at this point because they
really needed salt so if I do make these
again which I won't I'm definitely going
to season those with more salt at this
point so we have our mushrooms ready we
have our butter ready now all we need is
some snail shells which unless you know
someone that works at a French
restaurant and can borrow a some for you
you'll probably have to order online and
what you want to order our extra large
snail shells and yes they are beautiful
and by the way if you put one of these
up to your ear
you hear absolutely nothing
and then besides the shells another
thing you're going to have to order
online is one of these escargot pans so
these things are specially designed to
hold the shells in place while they bake
and there are other things you can use
which I'll cover on the blog post so if
you do make this what you won't you
don't necessarily have to have one of
these pans and then as far as how to put
these together could not be easier I'm
going to take my freakishly small wooden
spoon and use that to put a little bit
of butter in first so we'll prime it
with a little bit of our butter and then
of course we'll insert one of our moon
snails I thought I would try it again
still doesn't work so we'll pop in a
mushroom 1/2 push it in about halfway
and then we'll finish off by spooning in
another teaspoon or so of the butter and
that is it so I'm going to do 6 per
person and once those shells are filled
and placed in our escargot pan with the
butter facing up of course we'll place
those on a foil lined sheet pan at which
point those can go in a very well
preheated 450 degree oven for about 10
minutes or until browned and bubbling
and when these came out of the oven I
was so excited because they looked
exactly exactly like the escargot from
my favorite Bistro unfortunately that's
where the similarities pretty much ended
but at this point I didn't know that so
I transferred that to plates
adjacent to which I had two pieces of
equipment you're going to need to eat
these so besides ordering the shells
you're also going to need a snail fork
and one of these escargot clamps so at
this point I was pretty excited like I
said they look tre magnifique so I
grabbed ahold of one and I pulled out
that piece of style escargot and it
looked great it was glistening with that
garlic and parsley butter and it tasted
exactly like a half a boiled undersalted
mushroom with some butter garlic and
parsley on it the good news however this
stuff is still pretty amazing to dip
bread in so on that level I thoroughly
enjoyed this and then just to make sure
I went in for another one mostly to
confirm my conclusion this was pretty
much a huge waste of time while the
texture was not dissimilar to escargot
it really was missing that meaty earthy
flavor and if you're wondering why I
cannot eat like a normal person on
camera I wish I knew it's like I've
never used a fork before but anyway
that's it
so should you try this yourself probably
not unless you actually know a French
bistro chef that just recently converted
a vegetarian
and they're coming over for dinner this
would make a hilarious first course so
to those people I say I really hope you
give this a try and to the rest eeeh I
guess April Fool's so head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
